summary: Email correspondence from defense attorney Martin G. Weinberg to prosecutors regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein. The email requests preservation of evidence, DNA testing from the death scene, a taint review of seized emails due to attorney-client privilege, and inquires about the government's intention to dismiss the indictment.

persons.name: Martin G. Weinberg
persons.context: Attorney representing the interests of Jeffrey Epstein's family following his death; sends requests to prosecutors regarding evidence preservation, DNA testing, and the status of the indictment.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased defendant in the case 'US v Epstein'; the email discusses evidence from his cell and the potential dismissal of the indictment against him.

connections.description: Weinberg is acting on behalf of Epstein's family following his death, asserting attorney-client privilege over seized materials.

events.title: Evidence Found in Epstein's Cell
events.description: Ligatures and/or bed stripping were found in Jeffrey Epstein's cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

events.title: Seizure at Teterboro
events.description: Law enforcement conducted seizures at Teterboro, presumably related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Correspondence Regarding Case Dismissal
events.description: Email inquiry about whether the government intends to move to dismiss the indictment against Jeffrey Epstein.

keyFacts: A defense attorney for Epstein's family is requesting DNA be lifted from ligatures and bed stripping found in Epstein's MCC cell on August 10, 2019.
The attorney asserts that attorney-client privilege survives death and requests a taint review of emails seized from Teterboro on August 6 and from Epstein's NYC residence.
The email inquires if the government intends to dismiss the indictment against Jeffrey Epstein and if it will happen that day (August 12, 2019).
